Sir:—

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, with which you submitted a return of work done on the road to the Chapleau Boarding School to the value of $375.00; and in reply I beg to say that you may continue work on the road until it is in a fair condition for travel by team. D.C. Scott & Co.
Deputy of the Superintendent of Indian Affairs
Ottawa - Can

Dear Sir,

During a recent visit of Mr. Ogilvy of the Architect Department, the matter of clearing the land upon the site for the new School Building and adjacent was discussed between us. It was thought in all 50 acres should be thoroughly cleared. As there is a good steady stream which for the balance of the year will not be flooded at low water and further it necessary to engage a tram line from town, so that it would be possible for us to undertake this work. To cut and lay our acreage appears that the contract price in this neighborhood is $20 per acre. It will cost additional to get it stamped and in readiness for the ploughs. It would be required to be done as early as possible before the rainfall is heavy. There are quite a number of Indians in the neighborhood whom desired for employment, as soon as the work on the road is finished it would be more profitable for the School to do the work as in this case a great deal of poison could be saved for the school's fuel supply which would otherwise be destroyed. The timing of work in the vicinity of the site when building operations are to take place ought to be preceded with almost immediately to insure the safety of material or temporary buildings that may be placed there.

Believe me
Very faithfully Yours
Geo. Palmer
Ottawa, August 18th, 1914.

Ottawa, August 18th, 1914.

Rev. George Foster, Principal of the Chapleau Boarding School, has asked that fifty (50) acres of the land recently purchased as a site for the school be cleared. He requests that it be done by contract. The Department, however, prefers to do this work by day labour, under your supervision. You may, therefore, secure the necessary help to clear twenty-five (25) acres, and you should engage the school boys and teachers for such portions of the work as a team will be required for. Indian labour should be utilized as far as possible.

All portions of trees suitable for firewood should be trimmed free of brush and cut to suitable lengths for removal. These parts also should be carefully preserved for future use and fencing.

SURVEYS

Chippewa Boarding School.

Chippewa, Ont., May 16th, 1918.

Tom-Dalhousie Esq.,
Aust. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

On the road partly constructed and leading to the clearing done on the site chosen for the erection of the proposed new Boarding School, in the summer of 1914, is several yards of corduroy necessary in crossing a piece of heavy muskeg. This part, I believe, was intended to have been covered with gravel or earth of some kind.

Through this neglect and due to exposure to the weather, a number of the cross pieces have become rotten and as a result the whole crossing has become loose and is a great menace to our stock and horses which go in this direction to find pasture during the summer months.

Last summer one of our work horses, in crossing got his leg through an opening and hurt himself to such an extent that we were unable to work him for some time. It is in such a condition now that we dare not cross with a wagon. The material used was principally spruce, which does not retain its virtue for much more than three or four years when used for purposes of this kind.

I would be very glad if the Department would give me permission to remove this off the road. I think there will be sufficient wood found on the whole to repay us for the work of clearing it away, so that all that is asked for is permission to clear it away. I think we can do this as soon as our planting is done and the road becomes dry enough to work on.

Thanking you in anticipation, believe me,

Very Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

509272
Ottawa, 5th June, 1918.

Rev.Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 16th instant I beg to say there appears to be no objection to your proposal to repair the road leading to the Chapleau Boarding School in the manner in which you suggest. In removing the old material off the road you should be careful not to place it outside the limit of the road allowance if by doing so the adjacent lands are at all damaged.

If the corduroy is removed as you suggest you should re-construct the road across the muskeg in order to make it passable especially during wet weather.

Your obedient servant,

T D McLean

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Mr. Nicholson,

I am enclosing herewith a plan of the township in the vicinity of Chapleau, showing the land acquired from the Ontario Government in 1914, for the purpose of erecting thereon a proposed new Indian boarding school.

The location of this land, which consists in all of 1,184 acres and comprises Lot 1 in the 4th Concession 317 acres; Lot 2 in the 4th Concession 285 acres; Lot 1 in the 5th Concession 308 acres and Lot 2 in the 5th Concession 274 acres, is marked in red on the enclosed plan.

I have to request that you will have the location of the land proposed in place of the above, as a more suitable location for the school, marked on the plan and return it to this Department as soon as convenient.

Yours sincerely

Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

Replying to your letter of March 13th, there is a fairly good road from Chapleau to the point recommended for the school site. OTTAWA March 4th, 1919.

Mr. Duncan Scott,
Deputy Supt.-Gen., Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Further to conversation I had with you re Indian schools, principally the Indian school at Chapleau, the situation briefly is this; that the Department must at once, or at a very early date at least, come to the relief of these schools in a greater degree than has been done in the past, or such of the schools as cannot command outside support will have to be closed. Why do I say this? For the plain reason that after careful personal investigation, I have convinced myself, and I believe that I can convince anyone else who will take the trouble to go into the matter carefully, that the schools cannot be efficiently maintained on the present scale of remuneration. It is not necessary that I should belabour this point. It is a plain fact that must be faced. What does this mean at the moment? The Indian schools have been built up. I will take the Chapleau school as a practical illustration.

The Indians have sent their children there. They have come to look upon the school as a fixture, something to which they could look forward to as a means of getting the rising generation of Indian men and women into a position that would enable them to compete, at least on a reasonably equal basis, with the white men who are gradually forcing them whether they like it or not, into the white man's environment. On top of this comes the condition arising out of the influenza epidemic, and without entering into the details I feel that your records will show that in every district of which an Indian school forms a center, it will be found that there are in some cases hundreds of
House of Commons

OTTAWA

Indian children who are left complete orphans, and in many cases, destitute. I can give you specific instances of families of Indian children whose father went Overseas and died, and when the mother had died, the children now being cared for by other Indian families who have all their own problems to confront. It may be said that these children can be cared for by moving them out of the country altogether, but it matters not where they are, they must be cared for or abandoned to such charity as their case will command. I do not think that when once the case is properly understood, the Government will agree to either of these. In the first instance, it is not practical to move the children out. They will, in so far as they are able, refuse to go, and I do not think we can be very much surprised at that. In the second instance, we owe the Indian something better, particularly in view of the splendid record made when the manhood of Canada was called upon to do its part in the recent war. It just narrows itself down to this, that the Indian school is an absolute necessity if we are going to fulfill our common obligation to these people.

Then coming again to the school at Chapleau. The present building and equipment was provided as you are aware by the Anglican Diocese of Moosonees, the department taking the school over and reimbursing the Diocese for the money spent. The building was intended to accommodate twenty to twenty-four children, but was really only taking care of about sixteen. By the erection of a kitchen and the use of an outside room for a schoolroom with a dormitory upstairs, it has been possible to increase the number to about forty-five or six. The whole plant, however, has been recognized as entirely inadequate to meet the needs of the situation, and as far back as I think 1912, your Department had plans prepared and, I believe, all
appropriations made for the new school. The outbreak of war held this up, and in the meantime, in order that he might as far as in him lay meet the situation and relieve the Department from unnecessary expense, the man in charge of the school with his assistants literally worked like slaves. That their work has been splendidly efficient having in mind the difficulties under which they labored, no one who has any knowledge of the situation will attempt to deny.

The war now is over, pressing problems of every description are upon us and must be met, and in my judgment this is one of the most pressing, and I take the liberty of urging you as strongly as I am able to take steps at the earliest possible moment to go ahead with the erection of that building. As pointed out to you, I am satisfied that the site originally suggested for the new school is unsuitable. The two things vitally essential is a good tract of arable land and the possibility for an adequate supply of water. The next two things, possibly less essential, are convenience of access and the possibility for an efficient lighting system. In every one of these four ways the site originally selected fails to qualify. That, however, is only a minor detail and can without difficulty be easily overcome as there is an option of more than one first class site available.

Now coming to the school at Spanish. As I think you know, I am not conversant with all the details in connection with this, but I know that it has to do with the question of per capita remuneration, and I again urge that this be given your full consideration.

Yours very truly,

GBN/MP
March 13, 1919.

Dear Mr. Nicholson,

I have to thank you for your letter of March 4, with reference to the situation at the Indian school at Chapleau. I was discussing this matter with the Honourable the Superintendent General the other day, and am hopeful that we may be able to do something. In this connection I had asked you to locate the site you considered most suitable, and the one we decided on some years ago.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Mr. Scott,

As instructed I proceeded on the 26th ultimo to Chapleau for the purpose of inspecting an additional site proposed for the Indian Boarding School, and on the 27th and 28th ultimo accompanied by Mr. Prewer, Mr. Godfrey and Mr. Fife, of the electric plant, made a thorough inspection of the site offered.

The Austin site has many advantages in situation over that previously chosen, there being a fairly good road leading direct from the town to the old mill site (Austin site) and electric power plant, and on which (I am informed) the corporation of Chapleau will expend $500.00, putting this road in a thorough state of repair.

The power line also passes along this roadway at a corner of the site of 25 acres which Mr. Austin proposes to sell to the Department at a nominal price of $500.00. There are adequate facilities for drainage and water supply, also an abandoned railway siding into the property which if replaced would greatly facilitate the placing of materials for the building.

The site of 25 acres possessing all of the advantages stated, would be valueless for the purposes of a school, however, unless additional arable land of sufficient area can be acquired for farming purposes. Mr. Fife, representing Mr. Austin, expressed the opinion that Plot "B", containing about 320 acres, could be obtained from him for a nominal sum (exclusive of the water power site) but from a communication received this morning it would appear that he does not now wish to dispose of this plot situated between the proposed 25 acre site and the adjoining Crown lands which could be obtained.

Memorandum,

In connection with the completion of the purchase of the site for the school at Chapleau, the present position appears to be that in the case of Block "A", transfer can be made at once of that part required by this Department. Title to Block "B" however has not yet been granted by the Province to Mr. Austin.

The Department of Lands, Forests and Mines states that Mr. Austin is not a bonafide settler and that application can be made by this Department for Block "B" and grant obtained direct.

Mr. Nicholson suggests two courses,-either that this Department obtain Title to Block "B" from the Province and arrange with Mr. Austin to convey to him that part not required and presumably pay to him the price agreed upon for that part retained; or to have the Province issue patent to Mr. Austin and obtain transfer from him in the usual way. Mr. Nicholson appears to consider the first method to be the most expeditious and it would apparently be the one in which this Department is more fully protected. This would not however interfere with the immediate transfer of that part situated in Block "A".

Correspondence indicates that the actual site of the school is on Block "A" and this procedure would be the quickest method of acquiring a grant on which to commence building; the transaction involving Block "B" can then be completed in the manner most suitable to the Province. There does not appear to be any objection to the Title to the property required being covered by two separate patents.

The file does not show that a reduction in price on account of a smaller area being obtained, has as yet been agreed upon. The amount of reduction in area is from one-fifth to one-third of the total which it was expected to acquire and the reduction in price, therefore, should be at least $200.00.

These parcels however do not provide a sufficient area of tillable soil, either to operate the school economically or to sufficiently educate the Indian children in agricultural duties. Dear Sir:

I write you regarding the buildings over at the old school site here.

Since they have fallen into disuse, for teaching purposes they have more or less deteriorated through decay and the destruction wrought upon them by wanton hands.

After our removal to the new site, and during my Principalship, I aimed at keeping a close watch upon these buildings and upon one occasion had some young lads brought before the Police Magistrate for destroying the property and taking away articles left in the cottage. There were, however, several instances where we could not discover who was responsible for the destruction committed.

On one or two occasions Mr Indian Agent Geoffrey and myself attempted to ascertain the cost of removing the cottage to the new site, but we found that it would cost more to do this than to erect an entirely new building. To tear these buildings down, at the present cost of labour would mean that one would scarcely realize the amount in the material saved.

It has occurred to me that there is a possible use that I could put these buildings to; if the Department is willing to sell them and give title to about one acre of land upon and near which these buildings are situated.

I have purchased a dwelling in Sudbury, where I am intending to have my headquarters and expect to move my family there as soon as we are given possession of the property which will be about the beginning of October, and we might use the cottage as a summer residence, provided it can be purchased at a reasonable figure, and that we can get someone to reside in the old school building and take care of the same. Furthermore, I might find someone interested enough to purchase.

As an investment, I am prepared to offer the Department $1,500.00 for the two main buildings, the woodshed and smaller buildings immediately surrounding them; the conditions to include one full acre of land upon which the buildings are situated and immediately surrounding them.

The conditions will have to include the right to use the present road across the property leading directly to the town of Chapleau.

If your Department is interested in this offer I should be glad to have word from you immediately.

Believe me,

Faithfully yours,

Geo Prenter.

Dear Sirs:

Re lot 2, con. 6 Chapleau,

I have seen the Bishop regarding execution by him of conveyance to the Department of the above lands.

You will notice that the consideration mentioned in the transfer is $77.50, and that the value of the land according to the assurance fund affidavit is about $300.00.

The facts seem to be that some years ago the Diocese paid $250.00 purchase price for this land. Subsequently it developed that their vendor, an Indian, was a squatter and the Department took the stand that he had no title to convey convey but that the Diocese would have to purchase the land from the Government, which they did, paying an additional $77.50. The land has therefore cost the Diocese $322.50 and the Diocese is now asked to convey the land back to the Department at a cost of $77.50, notwithstanding the fact that the land seems worth at least $300.00 and cost the Diocese $322.50.

It is hardly necessary to say that the Church is not a profit-making organization, and has a good deal of difficulty in raising the necessary funds to carry on, particularly in this missionary Diocese. It would seem most unfortunate if the Diocese should lose this $250.00, particularly in view of the fact that the land is worth more than the price at which the Diocese is asked to reconvey.

I am sure that the Department is not aware of the circumstances and I am taking this opportunity of drawing same to your attention, trusting you will take the matter up with the Department with a view to having the Diocese paid an additional $250.00 purchase price, which amount will reimburse them for what money they have actually laid out on the property in the manner above mentioned.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Referring to your letter of July 21st, 1923, I wish to say that it has been brought to my attention that there is a movement in progress to purchase the site of the old Indian School at Chapleau for the purpose of purchasing it for the Roman Catholic Church, with the purpose of using it as a school and hospital for Indian children. You can at once see what this would mean. The fact of two schools practically side by side at Chapleau would tend to create confusion and possibly friction between the Indians and those concerned with Indian education.

When the Diocese raised the site in question in October 1923, the Department stated by your Acting Deputy that "this action was taken because of the advisability of having all land held by the Chapleau Indian Boarding School under the control of the Department."

I trust therefore that the misunderstanding above indicated will be adjusted so that no such sale to the Roman Catholic Church will be allowed to go forward without your knowledge. Moosonee.

(Signed) John G. Anderson

Sir:

The possibilities are that this boy will grow up wild as he has no proper place to live and his father is quite often away from the Reserve, and leaves him to roam around. Sir:

I have to report that the last time I was at Gibson Reserve, Joshua Thompson No.100 of the Gibson Band spoke to me about his two little boys, ages 7 and 5 years.

Joshua Thompson is living separate from his wife, or rather, his wife has left him. I have found Joshua Thompson to be a real decent hard working man, and when he had work he always supported his family, and if there is anyone to blame in this separation it is his wife, not Joshua Thompson.

These two little boys are just like crickets, they are as smart as they make them, and Joshua Thompson would like them to be brought up correctly. If he had work to go to at the present time he could not leave the children, and as there is an expectation that he might get work in the near future, he has made the request that the boys be accepted into the St. John's Indian Residential School, Chapleau.

I had the pleasure of having a visit at my home, from the Rev. A.J.Vale and I told him about this proposition of the Thompson children. He said he would let me know if he had room for them. I have received a letter from Rev. Vale this morning stating that there is room for the children. I have also received a letter from the Gibson Band asking me if I would make arrangements for the children of Joshua Thompson to go to the Chapleau School.

I do not think the other boys would pay for sending to the High School but Charlie Moore No.160 and Leslie Williams No.188 have no homes to go to and would be the better for being allowed to remain here longer. They will never make a mark in education but will do well in the outdoor work of the school on the farm and their characters would be the better able to withstand the temptations of surroundings on the Reserve if permitted to remain and be built up.

GIRLS.

No.0103. Eileen Rathburn This girl has attended High School now for two terms. She did well at the Examination last Spring. I regret to say she has not done so well this year and I would recommend she be given her discharge and allowed to return to her married Sister's home in Burlington Ontario, who has offered her a home. As she was sent here by the Department, I presume they will pay her fare home.

No.0120. Ruby Laforce. This girl is a big strong girl physically but has little ability as a student. She has asked me to try to get her a position as Domestic this summer if I can. She is not a member of the Band though she came from Baie. I would like permission to keep her on until I can, within a reasonable time get her placed. Her home surroundings would be very unhelpful if sent back to the reserve this summer.

No.0122. Jane Blacksmith. This girl has the makings of a fine type of woman. I think she ought to be given a chance to remain here longer and see what she can do in the classroom until she can be placed as a Domestic rather than be sent back to her father who has married again and the home is not fit for her to return to, with any chance to make use of her training here.

You ask my opinion of the other pupils who were sent to the High School. I would say with a few exceptions they did not warrant the extra cost to send them. Some had ability but would not apply themselves. Others did not have the ability to meet the standard and became discouraged. One, Darcey Black, a late boy, made very good use of his chance. He got his Junior Matriculation and took a course at Business College with Shaw of Toronto in Book Keeping and Accounting and passed with Honours. He is I believe now a Time Keeper at one of the Fire Ranger Districts.

Miss Emily Donald passed and took up Normal Training as a Teacher. She taught three years in a day school and is this Fall trying to return to Normal to make her Teacher Certificate permanent. She is applying to Normal School at North Bay this Fall.

Miss Ella Crean went to High School and then on to Train as a Nurse in Toronto. She has graduated and taken her R.N., and is employed at her Training home Hospital for as long as she desires to remain there.

Lorne Rathburn had ability but proved too lazy to carry on. He is now I believe an Orderly in a Hospital in Ottawa.

I do not think it pays to send pupils to High School unless they show special aptitude for it and I will be honest in not recommending any others if you allow me that privilege.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

Sir:

Enclosed please find a letter received from Annie Commandant, of the Gibson Band, who is now married to Patrick Stock.

I would recommend very strongly that this child be sent to the Chapleau Indian Residential School. The mother is not fit to bring her up and her husband does not want her there. I have been in communication with the Rev. A.J. Vale, principal of the St. John's Indian residential school some time ago, and he informed me that he would have room for some children there.

I would respectfully suggest to the Department that they consult with Dr. Stone re this matter, as he understands about Annie Commandant and the problem that she is. I am very glad that she has made application to get this child into the school because I am afraid it would be a very bad business if this child were allowed to be brought up by Annie Commandant. I am very glad that what was to me a serious problem has now been solved by Annie Commandant marrying Patrick Stock.

The consideration of the Department in this matter at their earliest will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

I beg leave to report that there are several children pupils of the Chapleau Indian School who have not returned to the school, and it appears that there is a regular organized effort to flaunt the requests that the children be returned, and I have been told that they were not sending them back, and as these families are getting relief I have advised them that their small allowance of relief would be cut off but they still insist that they will not send the children back.

There are three families who are persisting in holding the children at home giving various reasons why they should not be sent back and I would suggest authority be given to send a truant officer or Policeman after them as it is having a very bad effect with the other children at the school.

Then there is another case that of a girl about 15 years of age who was given a return ticket to go and visit her Aunt in Toronto and now she will not return the girl and as I am informed that living with this woman is no fit place for this girl I would also recommend that a truant Officer be sent to bring her back to the school, and unless firm action is taken in all these cases there will be a great deal of trouble in the future.

Waiting your instructions in the matter I beg to remain;

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

For the first time in my six years here I have had to call upon the police to act as Truant officer and bring back here children who have overstayed their Summer Vacation and the parents refused to send them back.

I have taken up the matter with the Chief of Police in the town of Chapleau and he has acted within his jurisdiction. The question arises as to what should be done in the case of children who are now in the jurisdictionality area to be safe he has asked me to write to you and see if you will in accordance with the Indian Act appoint him as Truant Officer so as to enable him to go to the homes of the said children and compel them to return to school.

All the children who have not returned are under the school age of 16 years and therefore ought to be returned. The parents refuse in the case of two children at Lissanable Ontario about 50 miles west of this town on the Railway.

I would take this matter up through the Indian Agent but he is away on leave of absence at the present. He told me he would write for authority to have them brought back. I have waited two weeks and no word has come yet, as I expect to be away from the school for a month on vacation. I thought it best to write you direct and ask you, if it meets with your approval, to appoint the Chief of Police here as Truant Officer to enable him to do what he is quite ready to do if granted such authority.

Will you be good enough to write him direct to the following address: Mr. Dery Chief of Police Chapleau Ontario.

I am yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.

In the same letter No. 65-1-10 Dated September 7th you ask after quoting a telegram from James Gideon of Timiskaming, if there is any reason the children should not be returned to the school; in reply would say there is absolutely no reason for not doing so. They are now at these I wrote to you in a previous letter in which I made request that you would appoint the Chief of Police Truant Officer so he could compel these children to be sent back to school. They have never asked for leave for holidays and the parents, as shown in the telegram have refused to have them back. The Chief of Police of Chatham made a trip up there for children. All of those whom he went to get came back quietly except this man's two children a boy and a girl. He defied the Chief and said he was out of his territory and that he would not send them but would get in touch with you.

He makes the ridiculous statement that the children were inflicted with "bad" like when they went here. Everyone here knows the reverse is the truth, they went here clean and each time they came back after holidays they had to be cleaned up. He says in a letter to me they went here dirty and for that reason he would not let them come back. You can appoint any person you wish to investigate. I suggest you write the Indian Agent for a character sketch of this man who has given a lot of trouble in the past to the Agent.

It is my opinion an example should be made of this case and compel the return of these children and avoid more trouble of this sort in the future.

Will you be good enough to give the necessary authority to the Chief and so convince these people they must obey the law.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.

Sir;

Replying to yours of October 4th, 55-1-10 re the admission of Bernice Kate Ains, to the Chapleau Indian Residential School, I have to state that Rev. Canon Vale has been a guest at my home for the last two or three days, and I was patiently waiting to receive this letter so that I would be able to send Bernice King to the Chapleau Indian Residential School along with Virginia Pawis.

Rev. Canon Vale left here on the Thursday morning train for Chapleau, with Virginia Pawis. Jack Stevens who met with an accident and has his hand practically blown away, and who has been in hospital up until a few days ago was also supposed to go to the school. I endeavoured to have him released from the Doctor's care in order to go to Chapleau with Virginia Pawis. I explained to Dr. Mason that they had a good hospital up there and had a trained nurse resident at the school, but he refused to allow the boy to go and said he would not be able to go for about a month. He is at present at home at Shawanaga Reserve, but has to attend the doctor for dressings. I presume that by the end of this month, he will be clear of the care of Dr. Mason and I will send him to Chapleau Residential School as arranged, and at that time will send Bernice King along with him, as he seems to be a bright little lad and would be able to look after her.

Dear Sir:

I found awaiting me here a letter from you under date of September 8th saying you approved of the admission of the two boys James and Phillip Davey, but would not pay their transportation to our school.

May I ask what proportion, or what is the limit you would be willing to consider a fair amount to pay for children coming to this school. It is difficult to get the children from close in as they have access to day schools.

The children at Moose Factory and vicinity are anxious to get education but the school there is filled to capacity. Hence they were sent on to us.

I shall be very glad if you can see your way clear to giving me a part of the costs at least.

May I also ask if you have taken any steps towards helping me to get back to school the two Gideon Children from Mississinewa.

Ottawa, October 15, 1934.

Rev. Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, I beg to say that you may submit to the Department your account for the transportation expenses of James and Phillip Davey to the Chapleau Indian Residential School. On receipt of this, the Department will consider what amount can be allowed.

Bringing children from Moose Factory to Chapleau is apt to be rather costly, and, while I recognize that the school at Moose Factory is filled to capacity, at the same time our Appropriation will not permit us to provide travelling expenses for taking children to a residential school situated at a long distance from their homes.

Regarding the Gideon children, Mr. Agent Godfrey was instructed in official letter of the 15th ultimo to arrange with the officer in charge of the R.O.M.P. Detachment at Sudbury to return these children to your school. You might make enquiries from Mr. Agent Godfrey with a view to ascertaining what action he is taking in the matter.

Dear Sir:

A letter has come through from the Mrs. Charles Gideon of Frank Ontario, parent of Robert Gideon, a pupil in our school No.153. In this letter she claims her son is 16 years of age and wants him to come here. According to our records he is not that full age. She claims his birthday is December of this year and it will be his 16th. That does not correspond with our record. These people have a way of trying to place the age to suit their own purpose. In this letter she says the Indian Agent promised her the boy would be allowed to go home. I spoke to him about it and he emphatically said he had done nothing of the sort.

I told the woman I would try to secure the discharge for this boy next summer but I felt sure you would not let him go at Christmas time as she had not sent him back to school at the right time this fall and the Department had to send for him. I shall be very grateful if you will uphold my stand in this case.

In her letter to her son she spoke of trying to get Mr. Selkirk of Frank to write to you and say the boy was needed at home to help the father. That is not true to the facts. It is merely an effort on her part to get her own way and have the boy here. The boy is quite happy here and needs the extra schooling.

I am yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

I have been asked by Wilson Assance Band to ask the Department of Indian Affairs if they could consider sending his three boys to a Residential School. The following are names and ages of boys, Solomon Assance age 13 years, Samuel Assance 11 years, Lazarus Assance 9 years of age.

I have had occasion to visit this man's home on different occasions and found it to be in a very filthy condition and certainly no place for children of this age. Assance apparently is not a very good manager and we have helped him out with clothes and so that they could attend school.

His Mother Mrs. Lazarus Assance who lives with them is very old and totally incapable of looking after the children consequently they go to school more often than not without anything to eat.

I have had this man get his house cleaned up several times but it soon is as filthy as ever so I think the Department would be doing a very great favor to these children if they were able to send them to a Residential School.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 23rd, 1935.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, regarding the children of Wilson Assance, who have recently been placed in the Chapleau Indian Residential School.

These boys were placed in a residential school on the recommendation of the Indian Agent, who reported as follows regarding home conditions:

"I have had occasion to visit this man's home on different occasions and found it to be in a very filthy condition and certainly no place for children of this age. Assance, apparently, is not a very good manager and we have had to help him out with clothes and shoes so that they could attend school.

"His mother, Mrs. Laurier Assance, who lives with them, is very old and totally incapable of looking after the children; consequently, they go to school more often than not without anything to eat.

"I have had this man get his house cleaned up several times but it soon is as filthy as ever, so I think the Department would be doing a very great favour to these children if they were to grant the request of the father to send them to a residential school."

In view of the above report, the Department considered that it was in the best interests of these boys to have them placed in a residential school and, as the Chapleau School was the only one at which there were vacancies, they were sent there. This school is well managed and the boys will receive every possible care and a good education. Owing to lack of accommodation at other schools, it will not be possible to arrange for their transfer. As for allowing them home on holidays, the Department considers that, in view of the report regarding home conditions, you will agree that such action would not be in the boys' best interests.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

the reason was I thought going

with me as you can see

Sir:

Replying to yours of July 12th, 65-1-10 re Lucy Gaikeshayongai, I was at Lower French Reserve on Saturday and made all arrangements for this girl to be returned to Chapleau this week. In this morning's mail I am in receipt of a letter from Thomas Gaikeshayongai her uncle, who states that he has got her a position with his daughter and her husband who are caretakers of cottages at the mouth of the Lower French, and that she will be there all fall.

I have written to Thomas Gaikeshayongai telling him that I am pleased with his arrangements and that it will not be possible for this girl to return to the school again, so I am advising him to keep her employed.

Sir,

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find the Report for our school for the quarter ending September 30th 1935.

I was away for a vacation so am a little late in getting this report in this time. I beg to draw your attention to a few things in connection with it.

First I wish to acknowledge your letter in which you gave reasons why it was difficult to grant the extra for High School in the case of Walter Heil No.65-I-22 Died Oct. 2-1935. I beg to say I am taking up the matter with the Authorities here and trust you will allow him to remain in our school until I can give fuller report on his case. His No. is II6 and is listed on this report.

I have inserted two names, George Iserhoff No. 221 and Grace Minnie Iserhoff No.079. These have not yet been approved by you.

In explanation I beg to state Bishop Anderson was in touch with the father quite before they were sent to us. They had no means of having them examined by a Doctor and sent them to us at the father's expense entirely. I have had them examined by the Doctors here and they are found suitable candidates for our school. The application forms are filled out and are now in transit back to the father to be properly attested and returned to me. I will forward same as soon as I get them. I know this is irregular. I could not well avoid it and I hope you will accept them under these circumstances. The father has for a long time tried to get these children into this school. The mother is dead.

No.142 Redfern Louttit is over the age limit of 18 years. I am asking for his discharge. I have arranged for him to go to Wycliffe College Toronto to train for the Ministry of the Church.

Rightly or otherwise I was under the impression the Department would carry pupils on after 18 years of age if they were attending High School hence my action in these two cases. I beg pardon for apparent error.

Yours very sincerely

Dear Sir:

In checking over the Report of this school for the quarter ending September 30th which went forward a few days ago, I found the name of Francis McLeod No. 0132 went through without an explanatory note to show why her name is still on the list although granted a discharge. The reason is this. Her father wanted her home in the Summer then wrote and asked for her to be kept here a little longer until he had things comfortable for her. This she did. He found it necessary to be away from home and will not return until Christmas time so I acceded to his wish on condition he should pay her fare home at that time. He has agreed to this. I have therefore kept her here and am giving her special instruction in the Domestic work preparatory to her going home. I trust this may meet with your approval.

I would like to ask permission to keep Charlie Moore No. 160 who is over 16 years of age so that he may fit himself for Farm work as he wishes to carry on when he leaves us.

No. 187, Stanley White Age 15 passed the High School Entrance this spring but did not get the $70 per cent to entitle him to the grant so he has asked to be allowed to stay and learn farm work so he can take a position as a farmer when he gets old enough to do that.

I shall be very grateful if you can give favourable consideration to the above requests. I may add neither of these boys have a home to go to and it does not seem wise to turn them off so young. I will do my best to locate them as soon as I can.

Yours very gratefully,

Financial Situation:
Mother has been supporting the children for about four years as father does not take responsibility and is not working. She placed both girls in Earlscourt Home when they came to Toronto in July 1936. She then obtained position as nursemaid for Muriel. The Board of Education refused a permit for work for her and her mother could not pay more than $18. a month, which she was paying for Myra, as she is only earning $50. a month and has to buy her own clothes and help the boy John. When at Sutton Muriel received $7.50 a month from the Indian Agent to enable her to attend High School. This was later discontinued when she left school to look after her father. Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to Muriel Snache. Provided there is accommodation for her in the Chapleau School within the number for which grant is provided, the Department has no objection to her being placed there.

During the academic year 1934-35, the Department allowed a grant for this girl to assist her in attending the Sutton High School. However, a report received from the Indian Agent on June 24th, last, stated that she had not attended regularly for the months of May and June and that she did not intend to write any examinations at the end of the year. As I presume she has not attended school since the first of September, I doubt the advisability of her attending high school in Chapleau this year.

The Department's position in this matter is that we have no objection to caring for the girl in the Chapleau School, but, at the present time, we are not satisfied that her past actions justify us in deciding now whether or not we will be responsible for her maintenance and tuition until such time as she completes a high school course. If you decide to send her to Chapleau, the Department's position as outlined in the preceding paragraph should be kept in mind.

Yours truly,

Dear Dr. Westgate,-

Canon Gould has forwarded to us a copy of a letter received by him from Lr. Sutherland. We understand you also have a copy of this letter and as there are some details in it which are not actually correct, we are writing to explain.

Muriel has been attending Jarvis Collegiate Institute here since coming to our Shelter. She has picked up this term's work and feels rather confident that she can do the first term exams in December with the exception of perhaps Geometry and Physiography, which she says are taught differently here. She, herself, is ambitious and wants to get on, and although it would appear she has not taken advantage of what the Department provided in Sutton, nevertheless we believe there are extenuating circumstances as Lr. Snache tells us that she had been working in Toronto, sending money to keep up the house. She became ill, went to the hospital here for an operation and when discharged was with a friend here for a few weeks until she was able to go home. Before her return Mr. Snache was ill and not working. They could not get relief and she, herself, was just recovering from her operation and unable to work. She lived in such poverty it was out of the question for Muriel to continue at school. She had no clothes and they had barely enough to eat. They could not pay the rent and could not keep the home. Eventually Lr. Snache obtained work with a family who have brought her to Toronto with them. She brought both of the girls with her and Lr. Snache went to live with relatives.

Muriel was particularly anxious to go to Chapleau as some friends of hers had gone there and this school has also been most highly spoken of by others. We are hoping that you can arrange to admit her after the Christmas holidays so that she can begin the new term in the High School there.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 18th inst., No. 65-1-10 re the above, and addressed to Canon Gould, General Secretary of our Society, I am taking the liberty of sending you herewith a copy of a letter from Miss Nora Lea, Supervisor of the Protection Department of the Children's Aid Society of Toronto, which furnishes some important information about the applicant in question which appears to have been omitted from earlier communications submitted to you.

When our General Secretary forwarded to me all the correspondence relating to this case, and asked me to deal further with the same, I was inclined to recommend to your Department that this Indian girl be admitted to our new Shingwauk School, but in view (1) of the large number of Indian girls recently sent to this school by your Department and (2) in view of the fact, set forth in the closing paragraph of the enclosed letter, that the girl herself was anxious to go to Chapleau as she had friends there, I changed my opinion.

Some time ago I notified the Principal of our Chapleau School of the possibility of this girl being admitted to that institution, and in the light of the information set forth in the enclosed letter, it appears to me that the case is one deserving of your help, and I sincerely trust you may be able to provide it, by authorizing her admission to our Chapleau School from the 1st of January next so that she may be able to attend High School in Chapleau along with the other two girls for whom I understand you have authorized the usual High School grant.

I commend the application to your sympathetic consideration and have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am writing to ask for the discharge of Lucille Po.CT14
Fanny Weeskachan. This girl came to us March 27-1928. She was
born on February 10-1922 so is now in her fifteenth year. She is
in the seventh grade.

We have had considerable trouble with her due to her
stubbornness. I have tried severe whipping and various methods of
punishments such as extra work instead of play, being sent to bed
early and loss of extra privileges but all seem to have failed
to cure her of exhibitions of temper and passive resistance to
the rules of the classroom and school in general. She has now
openly defied my orders to go to school even in the face of the
knowledge that this would mean her having to leave the school
entirely with a possible going to a reform school. This has had
over her no effect.

I am of the opinion it would be better to arrange for her
to be sent back to her own people at Rupert's House where she belong.
With your permission I will arrange for that to be done as soon as
I can do so.

I am now writing to request Reverend Bishop Anderson at
Cochrane to see when she could be sent back with some hope of getting
her back. Have I your permission to send her before the end of
the term? I think something must be done as it is practically a
question into question before the other pupils our power to demand
and obtain obedience to proper discipline.

I have not submitted this to Indian Agent Godfrey as she
is not one of his Indians and in previous instances of a similar
nature he has said it did not come under him.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

The Honorable the Superintendent General:

I have R.F. Pratt's memorandum of the 6th instant, with attached communication from Mr. George A. Leaman, R.F., and copy of letter he received from Nelson Assamoe, an Indian of the Christian Island Band - requesting that his three boys, who were placed in the Indian residential school at Chapleau, Ont., be transferred to the Mount Algic Indian Residential School, Huron, Ont., because of the fact that the latter school is closer to Christian Island and not so expensive when the father visits the children or when the children return to their home during the holidays.

I may say that in January, 1905, three boys of Nelson Assamoe - not Nelson - were placed in the Indian residential school at Chapleau, Ont. The local Indian Agent reported on the home conditions of the boys and stated that he visited the man's house on different occasions and found it to be in a very filthy condition and certainly no place for the children; that their mother was dead and the grandmother, who lived with them, was very old and totally incapable of looking after them. The Agent stated that it would be doing a very great favour if the children were placed in a residential school. The Mount Algic School was filled to capacity and the only institution at which there was accommodation was the residential school at

- Chapleau
Sir,

I beg leave to acknowledge receipt of official letter No.65-1-10 of July 7th, and in reply I regret to say that I find it hard to persuade the Indians of this Agency that they should take advantage of the opportunity of having their children educated in the Chapleau Industrial school, and while there are many children of school age most of them attend the public schools in the locality where they live.

There are exceptions of course where there are quite a number of children of school age which are not attending school. I have reference to the children of the Metagami Band and the Kapuskasing Indians, and these Indians do not wish to send their children out to the Chapleau school, but are awaiting the consideration of the Department in building a school at each of these points.

At all other points in the Agency except the above there are public schools where the Indians reside which makes it difficult to recruit sufficient children from the Agency to keep up the full number at the school.

Possibly if the Principal were to go out among the different bands and talk to the parents personally better results would be accomplished, but I find it very hard to impress upon the parents that they should take advantage of the opportunity to have their children well educated and well cared for, but I do believe better results would be accomplished were the Principal to make personal visits to the families with eligible children.

The Secretary, Your obedient servant,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, September 21, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing letter from John Twain requesting the transfer of his daughter to the Spanish Indian Residential School.

When this man placed his daughter in the Chapleau Indian Residential School he distinctly stated on the application form that his religion was Church of England. It is presumed that he is still recognized as a member of that Church and, under these circumstances, the Department is not prepared to transfer his daughter to the Spanish Residential School (See Sub-Section 2 of Section 10 of the Indian Act). As you were previously informed, the girl should return to the Chapleau School.

Relative to the attached account I beg leave to report that the two children belonging to Simon Cheshewabic of Brunswick Road were not back to school as promised after the summer, and that the parents refused to send them and Rev. Cannon Prewer was visiting this outpost on his missionary duties I requested him to try and secure them to the school.

The parents finally agreed to allow the children to return with Cannon Prewer but had no funds to defray their traveling expenses and Cannon Prewer brought the children direct to the school the entire trip taking two days and one night, and there are three items for board and room for which there are no receipts, and one item for taxic service.

I did not report the absence of these children feeling sure that the parents would return them but in seeing that they would not Cannon Prewer took the children if possible, and as a truant officer the coat was much needed on a reduced fare.

Ottawa, November 20th, 1936.

Reverend Sir,

The Department has now located the mother of Walter Neil - No. 115 of the Chapleau Indian Residential School. She is married to an Indian by the name of John Nolan and is residing on the Caughnawaga Reserve, near Montreal.

Please arrange to send Walter Neil to Caughnawaga at the earliest possible date. You should supply him with tickets from Chapleau to Montreal and you should notify Mr. P. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que., by wire, advising him of the date and time of Walter's arrival in Montreal, in order that Mr. Brisebois may arrange for someone to meet him.

The Department is arranging with the Branch of the Department of Pensions and National Health in Montreal to supply this boy with an artificial leg. Mr. Brisebois will be given definite instructions regarding this and Walter Neil should make inquiries from him when he reaches the Reserve.

The cost of Neil's transportation from Chapleau to Montreal will be paid on receipt from you of a properly certified account, in triplicate, to which you should attach the receipt from the railway company.

Yours truly,

The Secretary

Dear Sir:

I have to report, one of our pupils Joseph Kegeshyoongza No. 145 (who is just under 14 years of age) has given us considerable trouble by watching his chance to sneak away from the school and try to get back to his home. He was sent away in 1925 from the Shequindah Reserve through Indian Agent John M. Daly, Perry Sound.

He has now made three attempts to get away. The last was on Sunday afternoon November 29th. He succeeded in getting as far as Nemoos on the railway 16 miles from here. He was caught there and the Police brought him back to us the same evening. This was most fortunate as the night turned out a very cold one. Temperature went down to 43° below zero. You will see what the result would have been if exposed to that all night.

The consensus of opinion of the Indian Agent, T.J. Godfrey, the Police and myself is that he ought to be removed to safer quarters. They advised me to write you and send a copy of this letter to Indian Agent John M. Daly, asking for his early removal to prevent serious consequences. Once in the summer he eluded us overnight, that would be very dangerous in this weather.

This boy, in my opinion, is not criminally minded but mentally deficient and desperately homesick. We cannot safeguard him and will welcome your speedy action to place him somewhere under proper surveillance. In the meantime we shall do our best to keep a close watch on him by keeping him indoors as much as we can and well guarded.

Looking for an early reply I am yours very sincerely,

A.J. Vale
Principal.

October 30th, 1936.

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Canada,

Dear Sir:

I should appreciate your advice on the following facts: About ten years ago an illegitimate Indian child was born of Indian parents at the reserve at Cape Croker. It seems that the parents might have married had not the father been unfortunately drowned before the birth of the child in question. The child has lived continuously with a relative of the father on the reserve until recently when this party died. The child's mother married a man not an Indian about five years ago and these people now have two children of their own. The Indian child has been sent from the reserve to the home of the mother and her husband. The husband finds it difficult enough to provide for his wife and two children of his own and does not see his way clear to provide a home for the Indian child.

Under these circumstances would it be possible to have this child placed in an Indian school under proper supervision. It does not seem to me that the husband of the child's mother should be asked to contribute to this child's support but if the child has been properly returned to its mother and the mother is obliged to support it, the result would be the same and the hardship would have to be borne by the husband. Will you please give this matter your consideration and advise me if in your opinion another home can be provided for the Indian child.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir;

Replying to yours of Jan 5th, 64-22
re the child of Mrs. Leah Thompson, No. 137
of the Gibson Band, I have to state that while
I was on a visit to Gibson Reserve on Jan 9th,
I arranged with the mother to take the child.

This child is about 2½ years old. I brought him
to Bala and had Dr. Lindenfield examine him, then
brought him to Parry Sound. He is a clean healthy
little boy, and he had sufficient clothes for the
trip. I wrapped him up in a blanket and kept him
at my house until time for the early morning train
when I took him as far as Sudbury, I sent him in
care of the conductor to Chapleau. There was a lady
and her son on the train who were going to Fort
William and she kindly promised to look after the
little lad until they would arrive in Chapleau.
This is the cheapest and best way that I could
arrange the transportation.

I wish to state to the Department that this is
a phase of the work in connection with this Agency
that I like. This child was being brought up just
like a rabbit and I know that he will be well looked
after in Chapleau.

When I arrived in Sudbury, around six A.M.,
I wired Mr. Vale that the child would arrive in Chapleau
at 11:45. I was forced to stay in Sudbury all day
owing to it being Sunday, but I required a rest so
I slept most of the day, and arrived home on Monday
morning at 2:30 A.M.

From - Fred McLeod

Dear Sir:

Alec Cooper has requested me to write and ask permission for his daughter, Marion Cooper to be sent to the Hospital, as we are afraid she may be starting in the first stages of T.B., and if she gets out in time may be cured. She is always complaining of her left side being sore, and her breath is short and she seems to have difficulty in breathing at times, although she is able to move about yet, she seems far from being well.

This girl is about fifteen years of age, and also has fainting spells, and weakness of the heart during these spells. So we would be much obliged if you would let us know what to do about sending her out, the cost from here to Senneterre by Aeroplane would be fifteen dollars.

We would also suggest sending out Flore and Frances Miller, as Flore who is twenty-four years old is a cripple, and cannot do anything for herself, and Frances who will be six next summer should be sent to the Chapleau School, as they have no one to depend on here at Woswonaby, all their relatives are in the School at Chapleau, as their oldest Brother (Alfred) was drowned last fall, and since then it is only misery to keep this cripple girl here at Woswonaby, and we suggest she be sent to the Cochrane Hospital, this spring or early summer if you consider it advisable.

The little girl Frances we would be able to get out free as far as Senneterre, as the Canadian Airways Planes will be flying in our supplies for us again this spring, there will be plenty of chances for them to get out, and the cost for the other girl would be $15.00 to Senneterre.

We will be very much obliged if you would write to us at an early date, and let us know what to do about these Indians, who are at present dependable, on the Government for their living, the latter two are referred to. The other girl, Marion Cooper, although all her parents are still alive, but her Father only has one hand, and the other slightly crippled, having had both shot...

Dear Sir:

Following up our conversation over the telephone this morning I now write to inform you concerning the pupil, 182 Angus Gideon by name.

This boy has taken a nightmare several times lately. It seems to become more frequent of late. He had one March 24th and again April 10th and two spells of it last night. One shortly before 10 P.M. and another about 10:30. Mr. Smith spoke to Doctor Sheahan about his case. He said he would give some sedative to see if that would help. We talked over giving a change to the boy by letting him go home as an experiment to see if that would cure him. Doctor Sheahan thinks that would be a good thing and advised me to see you about it and report what he had said.

I have written a letter to the parents of the boy and enclose a copy for you.

Will you be good enough to write and inform the Department of the action we are taking in our efforts to help the boy. He is a very tall young fellow and is perhaps not growing his strength. He is about 14 years of age, in his 15th. In his nightmares, according to the boys in the same dormitories, he tries to get out of the windows. We place him on the second floor, but if he accidently did get out it would be dangerous. Therefore, it was thought to let him try the experiment of being at home and on the ground floor. He is quite a strong boy and might easily do harm to some of the others here. He pulls their beds to pieces and takes hold of some of the boys. They are getting nervous of him.

I trust you will approve of the action being taken even before we have time to get your consent. It may prevent a tragedy.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
Chapleau April 20th, 1937.

Sir,

I herewith enclose letter received from the Rev. Principal of the Chapleau Indian Residential school in connection with one of the pupils Angus Gideon. Ref. No. 162.

This boy has been acting very strange and the staff at the school were very frightened about him, being afraid that he might do bodily harm to one of the other pupils while under the influence of one of these spells, and after going into the matter with the Doctor, and the Rev. Principal we came to the conclusion that it was advisable to let the boy go to his home for a time and watch what results it would have on him.

The parents were willing to have him come home, and the boy was sent home last week, and if he improves he can be returned to the school, the matter should have been reported to the Department earlier but owing to my being confined to my home with illness I was unable to report the matter earlier.

I hope our action in the matter will meet with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir—

Your department very kindly sent us some children by the name of Hoff in the year 1930 from Odanak Quebec.

Two of these children now have passed the entrance one last year and one this year. The girl who passed last year attends the High School for the past year. She is now almost 18 years of age. In my opinion it is not worthwhile to send her any longer. She is not particularly bright as a scholar.

The boy is now almost 15 years of age. He has mental ability but not the necessary stability of character to make it worthwhile to send him to high school. In my opinion he would fritter away his time and get into all sorts of mischief in town.

The Girl is Irene Hoff aged 16 Pupil No. 0164.

The Boy is Douglas Hoff almost 16 No. 186.

In the case of Angelina Sands, daughter of Mr. Mrs. Jobe Sands, probably the parents or at least the mother and the girl are at fault. Angelina is 12 years old. Two weeks ago I summoned the parents, the parents and girl to the office under Section 10 subsection 3. The father apparently wants the girl to go to school. In fact, ask that we place her in a reformatory. Jobe leaves for work quite early in the morning and through neglect of the mother or girl she does not get up in time to go to school. Mrs. Sands said that she would work her up and then the girl would fight her. Mrs. Sands is pretty good on the fight herself. She lost her temper while in the office here and struck her husband [illegible] in the face. This girl is home most of the time but she stays with others fairly some. I have notified this family to appear at the office Friday, when up before I gave them a chance, as the father agreed to send the girl to school and the girl agreed to go to school. She went 4 days. My patience are about wore out with these last two cases. I am think unless there is a better effort to get these children to school I will have to fine or sentence to jail one of the parents in each case or other children or parents will soon try the same.

These girls are not a desirable lot to have at school, as some of them smoke cigarettes, it possible some of them have had contact with men, and general undesirable as pupils, but there is also the other side to consider. Others are watching the results in these cases, and if these children and their parents get away with it other will try the same thing.

If the Department has any reform school for girls where three of these can be sent, I think it would be the proper place for Harriett Gilbert, the Johnson girl and Angelina Sands. Jobe Sands has asked that his girl be placed in a reform school. I am quite sure Mr. Gilbert and Mr. Johnson would agree. If I believe the moral effect it would have on other children on the reserve would be good.

Your obedient servant,

Walpole Island Ont. Oct. 27th 1937.

Sir,

Re-truants.

As well as the usual cases of children playing truant of there parents neglecting to send their children to school regular, we have four chronic cases of truancy or neglect, in two Cases Ed. Gilbert and Sam. Johnson I believe the parents are quite willing to send their children to school, a 12 or 13 year old girl in each case. They send the girls to school but the girls run away, neither the parent or officer have been able to find the girls for some time. These girls were placed to a white family on the mainland where an Indian from another reserve was working. The Indians are still working for this white man but the girls are not there now. These girls have been picked up by the truant officer and taken to school on several occasions last week while the truant officer and R.C.M.P. were looking for these other girls, they saw these girls playing on the road some distance ahead of them. The girls ran into the bush and they have not since been seen. A few weeks ago the Gilbert girl was found staying with an old blind bachelor Joshua White, and it was also learned that she was staying with Moses White another old bachelor at time. Ed. Gilbert is doing all he can to cooperate with the officers.

The other two cases the children are staying at home. These are Joe Sands and Jobe Sands, girls 12 and 13 years old. Sarah Sands daughter of Mr. & Mrs. Joe Sands age 13 has not been to school since school opened Sept. 17th. In this case the mother is running around all the time, and leave the girl home to keep house. This family have been served three day notice to have Sarah in school, and have been summoned to appear in this office Friday A.M. They have informed the police that no one can take these girl out of the house or make her go to school, this is simply a case of parents neglect, the girl would go to school if she had a chance.

We have three other children here, that I wish the Department could place in some Residential school if at all possible, not that they are truants, but they have no home and are very badly neglected. They are the three children of Admiral Williams, the mother is dead, while the father is living he does not in any way look after his children; he drinks a lot and when he works he works on the M.S.A. side of the border, there is one girl about 10 and two boys about 8 and 6. The girl is a bright girl and make her home wherever she can find anyone to take her in, she likes to go to school but often has to stay away to look after some one children or do other work, she is anxious to go to a residential school having asked me on several occasions if I have found a place for her. The boys stay with their father or in his house, he is away almost every day and is sometime not home at night; these boys are alone and have to get their own wood and their own meals and carry their own water from the river or the neighbors in both cases it is too far for boy of their age to carry water, they come to school some, but under the circumstances they do not come regularly. They live on Squirrel Island and only one neighbor close by. With the cold weather coming on I am afraid the boys may perish with the cold or possibly have a fire and they are becoming under nourished. Even the Indians are complaining that these children are being neglected. Unless the father improves condition for the boys very soon something will have to be done for them. If we can not get them into a Indian Residential school we will have to place them somewhere and no doubt pay for the care of the two boys and quite likely the girl.

Our obedient servant,

Sir,

The above children are all over 12.

I have saw Sarah Sands, Harriet Gilberts and Abel Johnson parents, Jam. Johnson thinks it better that his girl be sent away to school as she runs away from home and school. Mr. Gilbert would prefer his daughter to be sent away but the other insist on keeping her home. Sarah Lother and Father object to Sarah being taken away. Sarah has not missed a day since she started back to school until today and the mother asks to keep her out for a funeral. Angelina parents Mr. Mrs. Jobe Sands went to Windsor or Detroit for a week end about 2 weeks ago and have not returned. Angelina went with them but returned Monday following and went to school for a few days but has not been to school for several days and do not know where she is.

Sarah Sands is not a bad girl, and will go to school if the parents will let her; they have promised to keep her in school if allowed to have her at home so far they are doing real well. I would recommend that Sarah be allowed to remain at home as long as she attends school regularly, but the other three are much better to be away from home and local surroundings as their parents have no control over them and they are out nights with very questionable company, and are a very bad example for other children at school.

Sir;

In the enclosed letter from Rev. A. J. Vale, principal of St. John's Residential School, and the list of boys not returned to the school, I have to report that the parents of the Hanibush children informed me that the children were getting along nicely and they would finish their schooling on Parry Island, either at the Depot Harbour School or at Ryerson Indian Day School.

The parents of Lloyd Decaire were given permission to have him home for the summer months, and faithfully promised to send him back in time. On questioning the father as to why he did not send his son back, he said that the boy had been sick and had a cold, and one hundred and one various diseases. He promised to send him to school at Wilson, to fill in the remainder of his term at school.

I explained to these parents, the harm they were doing the children of other parents by wanting a break in the regulations and that they could not get consideration in the event of them wishing to send any other child to the school, without the permission of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

There is on the reserve, an orphan daughter an only child of the late Mrs. Sophia Snake who had been cared for by her grandmother and step-grandmother who have a large family. This child has not been used very kindly by these people, in fact they have passed her on to other residents of the reserve, there seems to be no one to care for the child. I made application last fall for her admittance to an Indian Residential School, of which we not approved due to her age.

Is there not some institution in which this child could be placed, she is past five years of age, is intelligent and of clean habits, and a non-treaty Indian. I wrote the Kent Children Aid Society on November 4th regarding this child but received no reply.

An early reply as to the Department's ruling in the care of this child would be appreciated.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of November 25th and my reply of December 3rd with reference to the orphan daughter of the late Mrs. Sophia Snake, the Principal of the Chapleau Residential School is willing to accept this girl, provided she is in good health. You should have her examined immediately and, if the doctor pronounces her physically fit, she may be sent to the Chapleau School.

Miss Anne Crookes, c/o Reverend Canon Perkins, Chatham, Ontario, is going to Chapleau to join the staff of the Chapleau Indian Residential School. Miss Crookes is due to arrive in Chapleau on December 14th. Quite likely she will be leaving Chatham on Monday, December 13th.

I would suggest that, immediately on receipt of this letter, you telephone Miss Crookes and arrange with her to escort the Snake girl to the Chapleau school. This suggestion is made at the request of Reverend A.J. Vela, Principal of the Chapleau School, and you may so inform Miss Crookes.

You should, of course, secure a ticket for the girl to Chapleau and also supply her with any clothing that may be necessary for the trip. Payment will be made on receipt from you of a properly certified account, in triplicate. It is not intended that you should purchase any large amount of clothing for the girl, as she will be outfitted when she reaches the Chapleau school.

Dear Sir:

It is my painful duty to report two boys ran away from our school on Saturday evening last. They slipped out of the door unobserved just before time for a freight train to pass the school.

Just as soon as they were missed about 15 minutes later we sent out searches but were too late to ever take them as the train had passed. We notified the Police and they wired instructions ahead and the boys were arrested at Cartier and returned to us by the regular train in charge of the Conductor so as to keep down expenses.

I regret to say, one of the boys came recently from the Munsey school. He had only been in school here since noon of December 2nd. He went off with another boy recently sent here Jr. Indian Agent JOHN P. Had sent him to us November 17th. We were not at all suspicious of his tendency to run away. We are keeping close watch now on both these boys and will do our best to hold them.

Their names are Frank Jones from Shawanaga Ontario. Age 14
Eddie Noah from Munsey School. Age 10 yr

I shall be glad to have refund of same cost at your early convenience as I have to close my books for the year on December 15th.

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I wrote you yesterday in reply to your letter of enquiry re: Douglas Hoff No. 165. I reported he had run away from the school March 19th. He was located and arrested in Toronto March 21st.

I wired you this morning for instructions in regard to him, so we could have your advice before incurring expense of sending Police Escort for him and bringing him back here. I am of the opinion he would turn out a source of trouble to us if sent back here. I fear he might in his revenge perhaps attempt to set fire to some of the buildings or cause damage another ways to obtain his early release.

I wondered if it might be wise to send him off from Toronto direct to the care of the Indian Agent of his home district and let him try out the boy and see what he can make of him. I had told the boy we were trying to find work for him. Apparently he did not believe this and decided to take things into his own hands. I feel sure if sent back here he will run again at the first chance or give us trouble in other ways.

If he is sent, as suggested under commitment to the Indian Agent I think it will have good effect on the other boys here at school. I have informed them of our efforts to find work for him and of your letter in this connection. They realize what a mistake he made in running away.

Yours very sincerely,

My Dear Vale:-

Mrs Percy Hillier, an Indian woman from Waswanapi, was in hospital here last winter. I spoke to her about her two children and a young sister about 10 years of age, with the view of sending them to school; she could not decide without her husband and now Percy Hillier (husband) informs me that his wife died on July 1st and had told him of what I had said to her about the children. Percy, a returned man, is in a sad condition of health and may have to return to the Military Hospital at St. Anne de Bellevue. He wants to know whether his two children can be admitted to the Chayleau School, where other children from Waswanapi are.

Can you accept them? Percy is a whiteman. The young sister of the deceased woman is still in hospital here with Frances Miller both incipient cases of T.B.

Signed

(John G. Moosonee,)

Sir:

Will you please find an Indian School for a boy who hasn't a home of his own. I have a nephew 9 years old. Sir,

I beg leave to report that six pupils belonging to the Chapleau Indian Residential School ran away from the school the night of the 13th, three boys and three girls of about fourteen years of age.

These six children ran away some time during the night after the dormitories were closed and all the staff were in bed, immediately I was notified I had the Police have all trains searched both East and West after not being able to locate them near the school or town, during the day messages were sent along the railway and during the next night the Boys were located at Cartier a distance of 135 miles East and the Girls were located 135 miles west at White River and I immediately sent Truant Officers to bring them back, and they are now all at the school again they having all been brought in on the railway today.

I am attaching the accounts for the expenses of the exploit and hope that it will not occur again, and have asked the Staff at the school to keep a little closer watch on these older boys and girls and see that the same does not happen again.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to reply to the departmental letter of December 29th in regards to Mrs. Ada Ashkewe, and I beg to say that there are three school age children, of protestant religion, who have not been attending school regularly.

I have been trying ever since school opened in the Fall to have these children attend school regularly but it has not proved very successful. I have also sent the R.C.M.P., Mr. Langley, on two different occasions to try and scare Mrs. Ashkewe into sending her children to school but it has not proved satisfactory. Her husband has not lived with her for some years and she is a very capable mother and is willing to look after the children properly. I would recommend that the children be sent to a residential school as soon as there is an opening, if the Department approves of it.

I have no letter on file regarding prosecuting this woman but when Inspector McGookin was here on his last visit he advised me to have the R.C.M.P. interview Mrs. Ashkewe and try and make her send the children to school or the Department would take some measure in regards to the children.
