Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your 32-0-10 of the 30th December, enclosing a letter addressed to the Honourable Minister, by Mrs. Andrew Jonathan.

In reply would advise you that both Mrs. Jonathan and her husband are a constant trouble to this office, as they frequently quarrel, then seek the help and advice of this office, but fail to follow it out.

Some time in December Mrs. Jonathan had her husband up in the Brantford Police Court for assault. On the day the case was before the Court she came into this office and said that if the cheque for children's arrear of interest came not to permit her husband to have it as the children would derive no benefit from it as her husband would only "booze it away".

On the other hand the husband had previously told Mr. Hilton Hill, the Chief Clerk, if Mrs. Jonathan received it she would only waste it running around.

So I instructed the M.C.P. Police to bring both parents to this office after the case was over, obtained Jonathan's endorsement to the interest arrear cheque and then sent the parents and the children out with Mr. Hill in order he might supervise the spending of the money wisely to purchase some much needed footwear and clothes for the children.

As I have already explained the parents are continually quarrelling, the wife complaining the husband does not support the family properly, while the husband claims his wife runs around with other men. Mrs. Jonathan also had expressed concern about the behaviour of the 14 year old daughter, Jessie.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant with reference to the children of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Jonathan.

In view of the information contained in your letter the Department approves the admission of Edna, Alvin, Percy and Jessie Jonathan to the Chapleau Indian residential school. This is the only Indian residential school under Protestant auspices that can provide accommodation for pupils at the present time.

I enclose a transport requisition which will enable you to purchase the four tickets from Brantford to Chapleau. It should not be necessary to accompany these children as they can be placed in charge of the train officials and a C.P.R. train for Chapleau leaves Toronto every night. You can no doubt send the children from Brantford on a late afternoon train and this will mean that they will only be in Toronto for a short time during which period the Traveller's Aid official will look after the children.

If you find it necessary to incur any other expense in connection with sending them to Chapleau you may submit the usual voucher.

It would be advisable for you to wire Rev. A.J. Vale, Principal, Indian Residential School, Chapleau, regarding the exact date and time of their arrival in Chapleau in order that he may meet them.

Dear Sir:

I write to consult you regarding the best method to deal with some of our worst problem girls at this school.

The following girls were sent to us from Muncey vicinity because they were hard to handle down there. We have so far been able to restrain them from running away from school. But their behavior is such at school that they are spoiling the other girls. They are very rude and obstreperous to the ladies of the staff and very hard to control. Can you remove them to some other place and relieve us of the difficult task of handling them. They have been severely punished but that does not last long.

The girls I refer to are Harriet Gilbert Age 14, Elsie Martin Age 14, Josephine Whyte Age 14, Angeline Sands Age 14.

Dear Sir:

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 65-1-10 of May 11th, concerning the intended discharge of Elsie Martin, a pupil of the Chapleau Indian residential school.

While Elsie Martin was a resident of Caradoc Agency when she was placed in Mount Elgin residential school some years ago, she is the daughter of Samuel Martin of the Chippewa of the Sixth Band of Cape Croker. Her mother was an Antone of the Oneida Band, who died previous to Elsie being placed in the school.

Elsie has a grand-mother who lives on the Oneida Reserve on occasions, one Mrs Ethel Antone, but this girl would not be entitled to reside at this Agency and it is my suggestion that her father be consulted as to her leaving school and having a proper home to keep her and failing to find a proper home at Cape Croker I would then suggest that this girl be retained in the residential school until she is of an age that she can care for herself or employment is found for her upon discharge from the school.

I have been wondering if it would be possible for you to organize these girls into a vocational group and have them undertake crochet work, hand loom weaving, etc. These projects might be undertaken on the understanding that, when the goods are sold or disposed of, the girls would receive a certain amount of the sale price. In this way the girls might be encouraged to become less of a problem in the school and encouraged also to save a little money toward their maintenance when they are discharged a year or so from now. You might at your convenience let me know what you think of this suggestion.

We have learned from experience that it is not possible to commit these girls to a correction home. In other words, they have not at this date been guilty of an offence that would justify such action. It is altogether likely, however, if they were permitted to return to the reserves, all of them would become problem cases in a comparatively brief period of time.

Dear Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter Dated June 3,
1939 under No.65-1-10 referring to my request for the removal of
some girls.

I note the conditions at their homes as set forth by the
respective Indian Agents, letters enclosed for my information.

In regard to your suggestion of forming these girls into
a vocational group for Crochet work, hand loom weaving etc. I am
very pleased to have this suggestion. We have taught these girls
to knit and sew for themselves and to make their own dresses to
some extent. We are well equipped for the hand loom work. We have
not the equipment or the rooms. I have found some years tried to
get the Department to help us to have a manual training equipment
for both boys and girls. The first step must be enlarged space
and equipment. If this can be provided we will willingly undertake
to try to establish such work and provide the instructors.

I have to report, since my last letter three of these
girls organized a runaway group taking three others with them on
the night June 9th. They made rope out of sheets tied together and
took off a screen from the second storey dormitory and escaped
during the night. They went through Chippeau in the dark and
walked along the railway track about 25 miles West. The Police were
informed of their going and brought them back. I tried a new sort
of punishment this time. I clipped their hair short and the Police
gave them a severe warning of what would happen if they tried again
to runaway. Four of these girls broke from the clasp of the Police
and hid in the woods. He got help and all were safely returned on
11th.

I will do my best to control the girls. They are very angry
at not being allowed home for holidays.

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter 7-0-10 of February 21st, 1939, wherein you instructed me to write in July in regard to the Stephen Smoke family #145, Alnwick Band, with a view of placing the children in one of the Residential schools on September 1st, I beg to advise that if accommodation could be secured for four of the children I think it would be in their best interests that they be sent. These children are showing the results of neglect. They are under nourished and although last winter relief grants were given them from time to time I do not think the food could have been properly prepared for them. Although Stephen Smoke has a wood lot and plenty of time he did not get out a supply of winter wood last year and was unable to move this year to obtain it and as a result last winter the children burned for fire wood and nineteen panels of rail fence from band property in the neighborhood of their home as well as using board stripped off a barn belonging to the band in the amount of about $250.00. I have incidentally had Smoke replace these rails and instructed him to replace the boards removed.

There are five children in the family, Leonard 17, Beatrice 15, Bernard 12, Lloyd 10 and Violet 7. I would recommend that the four younger children be sent.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I regret to have to report Elsie Martin, a pupil whose removal from this school I have at two different times and request, last night organized an escape from the senior dormitory of our school the following girls:

- Elsie Martin age 16
- Jessie Jonathan age 14
- Margaret Jeffries age 14
- Margaret Kitsonbrath age 16
- Dorothy Sayors age 12

The latter two girls were caught in town last night and held by order of Chief of Police and brought back to school this morning.

The other three girls were reported to have got on a freight train about midnight and were reported as being at Cartier on C.R. railway this morning. The Chief has gone by train to bring them back.

I beg to say the girls got out of the dormitory on second storey of the school by breaking a wire screen and made a rope by knotting their sheets.

The Indian Agent and Police are cooperating with us in trying to control the situation. The three girls who got on the train have run away before and were punished by having their hair clipped short. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant in connection with the truancy of certain girls from the Chapleau Indian residential school. The Department has very carefully considered the reports that have been received regarding the action of these girls at Chapleau and an endeavour has been made to place them in other institutions but without success. It has, therefore, been decided that Elsie Martin and Jessie Jonathan should be returned to their homes.

Elsie Martin comes from the Cape Croker Reserve and the nearest railway point is Marton, Ont., to which point she should be sent. Jessie Jonathan is from the Six Nations Agency.

We want to make certain that these girls reach their home Reserves and consequently either yourself or some reliable person should accompany them. I would suggest that you leave Chapleau on Thursday afternoon, reaching Toronto Friday morning. I am writing to the Indian Superintendent, Major L.F. Randle, at Brantford to have some person meet the C.P.R. train arriving in Toronto from Chapleau on Friday morning and take Jessie Jonathan to the Reserve. The party who has brought the two girls from Chapleau can then proceed to Marton with Elsie Martin. The Indian Agent at Cape Croker is being instructed to be in Marton on Friday afternoon.

With reference to your letter 65-1-10 of September 5th wherein you instructed me to send the four children of Stephen Smoke of the Alnwick Band to The Chanieau Indian Residential School, I beg to advise that I have found it necessary and cheaper to have the children sent by car to Toronto last evening in time to catch the 10.45 (Standard time) C.P.R. train from Toronto Union Station. The cost of their transportation was $10.00. They would have had to wait in Toronto for some hours in order to make connections if sent from Cobourg, the nearest point on the railway. I would then have had the costs of transportation from Roseneath to Cobourg plus Railway fare.

I called at the Smoke home yesterday afternoon and found the children practically destitute of clothes and with practically no food in the house. Therefore, asked an Indian woman to come in and cook them up a good meal and proper food for them to have their breakfast as they would be on the train from 10.45 last night until 11 o'clock today.

In the p.m. of the 16th inst., a telephone call was received at this Detachment from the Indian Agent of the Cape Croker Indian Reserve who stated that he would like the writer to patrol to that Reserve and take over one Jessie Jonathan and escort her back to her home on the Six Nations Reserve and then went on to explain as follows:- This girl and another Indian girl, Elsie Martin, were expelled from the Chapleau Indian Residential School and were being escorted from Chapleau by the Chief of Police of that point. The Constable was to escort the two girls as far as Toronto where Jessie was to be given to Mr. Randal, the Supt. of the Six Nations Reserve and then the Constable was to continue and escort Elsie to Wiarton, Ont. where he, the Agent of the Cape Croker Reserve, had ordered to meet her and escort her to her home at Cape Croker. The Supt. of the Six Nations Reserve failed to meet the train at Toronto and the Constable then brought both Indian girls on to Wiarton, Ont. where the Indian Agent took charge and escorted them to the Cape Croker Reserve.

In view of this request, a patrol was immediately made to the Cape Croker Reserve where Jessie Jonathan was taken over and on the same date escorted per police car to the Six Nations Reserve and there turned over to her father, Andrew Jonathan. The writer then notified the H.C.O. in charge Chawaken Detachment that this girl had been returned to her home on the Reserve. The writer returned off patrol in the a.m. of the 16th inst.

Dear Sir:

You asked me to write you in connection with Frances Hoff, a pupil No. OI79 of this school.

I beg to report this girl came to us in the Fall of 1932. She is about 14 years old. She has given us a lot of trouble at different times. Frances has a very violent temper and capable of doing anything at such times. She did once threaten to use a knife and pointed it at one of the ladies of the Staff. She was severely whipped for this offence.

Frances has often been implicated in various runaway groups. She, with five other girls, once got as far as Nicholson on the railway and had to be brought back by the police. She was again severely whipped for this. Whipping does not seem to effectual in stopping her.

Recently she has organized a group of girls to abuse a small girl of six years to such an extent that marks were left on her from striking her with a stick. The little child was so intimidated by Frances that she stubbornly refused to tell the truth. I got it from some of the other girls. I was also told Frances and one other girl suspended the little girl by a rope, they had surreptitiously secured, until the child was almost unconscious. This took place in a secluded part of the lavatory.

Last week Frances tried to effect a runaway of eleven girls. This was found out in time and prevented. She tried to get the girls to agree to fight if they were to be punished.

I think if you could arrange for this girl to be sent to her home, Oshawa Quebec, it would be a good solution to the problem and help us control the girls and prevent serious trouble.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir,

I beg leave to enclose letter received from the Rev. Principal, and which is in reply to a request from me to give me particulars of this young pupil.

My reason for asking the Rev. Principal to give me this report was because of several reasons first apparently the school staff appear unable to do anything in the way of controlling this Pupil No. 179 Francis Hoff, and constant trouble is experienced as the girl is a real menace to the school discipline, and in addition to her encouraging the other girls to run away she is constantly causing trouble, sometimes doing things that are serious such as climbing out the dormitory windows and meeting young boys from the town and near vicinity causing a lot of expense in locating these girls and bringing them back to the school, and as the school staff apparently can not control the situation without constant night control by guards the entire night I would recommend that this girl be discharged and sent back to her home.

We expected that when the other two girls were sent away and that having no chums to go with her that she would settle down, but such is not the case she has conducted herself very badly ever since and constantly causing serious trouble, this girl is 14 yrs. of age and very bad tempered and aborn agitator and bad example to be left among so many young girls.

Your obedient servant,

I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the Chapleau Indian Residential School shows the following pupils over the age of 16:

No. 193 John Jeffries
No. 0212 Julia Sickles

Permission for the retention of Julia Sickles, No. 0212, for the current academic year was approved by official letter of June 19, 1939, but no approval appears to have been given for the retention of John Jeffries, No. 193. In this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

Dear Principal Vale:

In reply to your letter of the 12th inst., and relative to Dorothy Saylors, I have certain proposals to make.

I can quite appreciate your difficulty, and the concern of the girl's father, and would like to help out in the matter if at all possible. Of course, what I propose to you would be entirely subject to the wishes of the Department. We have a full school, and many young ones waiting to be admitted so that if this girl came to us, she would be keeping away younger child who, perhaps has even a better right for admission than she has.

If the Department sanction the transfer of Dorothy Saylors from your school to ours, I shall be glad to have her, and will do all in our power to help her make good, but with the distinct understanding that if she does not do her part, or if her progress in school, or in controlling herself is not satisfactory, after she has been here one year, then she shall not remain with us.

This may sound a little strange from the usual way we have taken, but I really think we have not laid enough emphasis on the privilege of having the chance of an education, and for that reason a great percentage of our pupils have not valued it until the privilege has passed beyond their reach. We have fifteen attending Tech. and High school this year, and if, at any time I find any of them abusing the privilege given to them, I shall immediately recommend their discharge. I find this method raises the standard in the eyes of these pupils.
St. John's Ind Res. School,
Chapleau, Ont.

Dear Principal:

Mr. Amon Saylors of Chapleau, who says he was an old pupil of Shingwauk School is anxious for me to see if you would accept his daughter Dorothy as a pupil in your school. Dorothy is 13 yrs. old and is being confirmed in May next.

This is the position: Mr. Saylors has had four of his children at this school, three girls and one boy. Two of the girls and the boy have done well, and graduated to High School, and Dorothy is now with us, and we expect her to pass her Entrance this Spring.

The other three children all did well and gave no serious trouble to us, or to their fathers, until they got free to go to High School. Then in each case they got out of hand, due to their being in touch with their relations living town in the free time from High School at noon etc. He fears the same fate may overtake Dorothy, and thinks if she were removed from this influence in town she might be kept from falling into the evil ways of the others.

He made a direct application to the Department last Fall, but they paid no heed to him. He asked me to see if you would be willing to accept her for the full term whether she passes or not into High School. I am quite agreed to let her go to you if you wish to try and see what can be done in this case. Will you write and let me know what you think. I will be frank with you. The girl is not a bad child in many ways, but occasionally has a fit of temper and needs to be helped over that time. We can control her here so long as she does not go to High School, we do not think she would be easily managed here if she goes to High School and only returns here at night.

Write and let me know what you think about it.

Yours sincerely,

Signed, (A.J.Vale, Princ.)

Dear Sir:

The three children are now under their grand'mother's care and this morning, she came in twice to tell me that the boys have to be taken away from her because they are too rough and she is sick herself and cannot keep them any longer; the best she can do for her daughter is to keep the little girl.

Mrs. Angus tells me she does not know where her daughter, Mrs. Tewsha, is at the present time, in Montreal or in the United States; she claims not to have received any news from her since she left, and she tells me her daughter will not come back until the boys are gone to some school, because she could not support the scene of their departure.

Oka, August 3rd, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo relative to the placing of the two boys of Mrs. Norman Tewesha (Theresa Teweshaw).

In reply I beg to say that on May 9th last I was applying to have these two boys placed at the Chapleau school and your letter of the 15th of May told me it was impossible for the time being to place the children, but only after the summer holidays.

I consider that the boys should be placed because the mother having left Oka to work in Montreal or in the U.S., she left her two boys and one little girl under the care of her mother, Mrs. Louis Angus, here in Oka, and the poor woman cannot keep the boys any longer; they do not listen to anybody and most of the time they are away from our local school.

The mother being away from home and the boys, I may say, left to themselves, I consider it necessary to have them placed as the mother, I believe, will not care much for them now that she has left her home and tasted the free life. So, in the best interests of the boys, I recommend their placing into a residential school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Indian Affairs Branch
Training Division, Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

With regard to the enclosed application for admission to The St. John's Indian Residential School of Louisa Minnie Davies.

She is really an orphan who was adopted by Joe Davies, chief of the band when about a year old, since then they have given her great care and attention, they have no children of their own, and as they both attended residential schools when young, they want the child to have the same chance.

They will be going into the bush to trap soon, in past years Mrs. Davies has stayed at the Reserve and kept the child, but would like to go into the bush this year with her husband, and therefore would like to put the child in the school, where she will be well cared for and get the education they desire her to have.

As they are both very reliable people, who have the child's welfare at heart, I would recommend that she be admitted to the school, although at the present time she is only five, but will be six in December.

Your obedient servant,

AGENT'S REPORT FOR MONTH OF SEPTEMBER.

During the month we had some trouble with children running away from the Indian Residential School here. It started with one boy, sent here from the London Juvenile Court, who escaped and has not been caught to date. A few days after two girls tried, but we kept such a close watch on the freight trains that they could not get out of town, and they returned to the school. Then about a week ago three boys tried it; they got as far east as Cartier, but could not get through the police check, and they also returned to the school. After their privations in the bush, and punishment on their return, they will be a deterrent to any others who may take a notion that they would like to travel.

F. Matters,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

The examination of pupils at Charlevoix Residential School by Dr. Mary McKenzie Smith

Dr. Smith reported 13 cases with elevated tonsils, and that these required removal at once. I know that Dr. Smith has wide experience as regards throat conditions among school children, but in the case of Indian children my experience is that the fever elevations they have are the better. These cases have not reached any notice. My opinion is that from these cases would be benefited by removal of the tonsils when warmer weather comes, but should not be done during the winter. I find that if there is bad tendency in the case of these children as regards tuberculosis or any form of tuberculosis in the way of tubercular involvement, removal of the tonsils is often a questionable procedure.

With regard to the children who defective vision we are at a disadvantage in that no physician makes visits here. We have a local physician who can help some of them by fitting them with glasses. Some have had more or less serious conjunctivitis which after healing leave the eyes different in the appearance to fit with proper glasses.

Yours very truly,

J.J. Sheahan

Sir,

I have your letter of January 16th enclosing Dr. Sheahan's report on the pupils of the Chapleau Residential School. The Department desires to disclaim any intention of criticising Dr. Sheahan's professional opinion, but I think it permissible to observe that Dr. Sheahan has not furnished the Department with any reports on the health of the pupils and that the report of Dr. Smith, who was called in by Dr. Sheahan, suggested that some corrective work was immediately required.

Facilities for medical attention for the pupils of the Chapleau School are very convenient and good, and the Department is quite prepared to leave the treatment of individual cases to Dr. Sheahan's judgment if assured that adequate attention is being paid to the pupils' health by means of regular examinations and a study of individual cases.

The Director of Medical Services wishes me to observe that while he cannot presume to instruct Dr. Sheahan in treating any pupils under his charge he has had reports from many parts of the country to the effect that the removal of tonsils was one of the most efficient ways of dealing with tubercular glands of the neck.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing a communication which you received from the Principal of the Chapleau Indian Residential School requesting to have dental attention provided for Charles Wesley, who is attending high school; also requesting permission to have the teeth of all the pupils examined by a dentist and furnish his report as to the dental work required.

In reply I have to say that Dr. R. J. Gawley, Chapleau, may examine the teeth of all the pupils and carry out the work only that is absolutely urgent at the present time. This includes the fillings required by Charles Wesley. Dr. Gawley will be allowed remuneration at the same rates as previously paid him, as mentioned in official letter dated September 26, 1930 viz., $1 per amalgam filling; $1.50 for compound cavities, 25 cents each for ordinary extractions and 50 cents each when a local anaesthetic is used. In view of the recent orders for strict economy, it is to be distinctly understood by the Dentist and the Principal that only the most urgent dental work is to be carried out, and it is not intended that any large account be rendered at this time.

Dr. Gawley should prepare his account, in duplicate, together with a list giving the name of each pupil receiving attention and the work performed in each case. This account is to be handed to you to be attached to a proper voucher form, which you should certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

Please ascertain from Dr. Gawley if he will undertake the work, and, if so, arrange with him to carry out same at an early date.

This fee is not subject to the usual deduction of 10% as it is a specific arrangement for an individual job.

You are being supplied with an additional copy of this letter and it is desired that you will discuss it with the Reverend Canon Vale and Doctor Gawley. If you can make the necessary arrangements with them and if it is the opinion that the work should be taken in hand now, you need make no further report if the work is not expected to exceed three days. It is understood under this arrangement that the dentist will be called upon to spend the whole of three full long days, but it is not necessary that he should do it on three consecutive days.

In making up his accounts the dentist is only required to specify the number of days' work he does and add on the face of the account form a list of the fillings, extractions, etc., which he has done. There is no object in making a long list of the pupils' names, though the principal will, undoubtedly, wish to preserve such a record.

To make this plan a success the principal must see that the pupils are organized into proper groups so that the dentist's time will not be wasted. In most schools the medical officer carries out the preliminary inspection and the dentist is only required to do the actual work. There is room in these proposals for any minor variation of the plan proposed which will meet the local situation.

July 17th, 1934

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of July 9th enclosing Dr. Gamley's estimate of dental work at the Chapleau Residential School, I wish to inform you of a new arrangement that the Department is bringing in for work of this kind. It has been found more satisfactory for all concerned to employ a dentist on a daily basis and the fee offered by the Department and accepted everywhere by dentists, is $30 per day which covers professional attendance and supply of ordinary materials. The class of work required is extractions and repair of cavities with a cheap type of filling. The amount of work estimated by Doctor Gamley, who has experience in other places, would seem to require about three days.

Whether it should be done now or after the beginning of the new school year is not apparent to the Department, but might be decided between yourself and the principal of the school.

By this method in the course of a year or two the dentist finds himself able to get the children's teeth in a fairly good state of repair, after which only one or two days' work per annum is required. Many dentists have been somewhat reluctant to accept the fee offered in the beginning but after a year's trial have expressed themselves as not only satisfied but interested and anxious to co-operate in keeping up the dental condition of the pupils. Where the dentist lives a long way from the school it is the custom to pay his travelling expenses, but this would not be the case at Chapleau.

T. J. Godfrey, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chapleau, Ont.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th instant regarding the trouble you are having with cockroaches, I beg to say that Bulletin No. 112 of the Department of Agriculture suggests the following:

"Cockroaches may be readily controlled by means of sodium fluoride. This material should be lightly dusted in places frequented by the roaches such as about sinks, baseboards, cupboards, hot water pipes, etc. The sodium fluoride adheres to the legs and antennae of the roaches, and in cleansing themselves the insects are poisoned by it. Sodium fluoride retains its effectiveness and may be left undisturbed as long as convenient or until the cockroaches have completely disappeared. As this chemical is somewhat poisonous reasonable precautions should be taken to prevent children or domestic pets from gaining access to it.

Two other materials which form the basis of many proprietary roach powders and which often are recommended, are pyrethrum and borax. Pyrethrum insect powder is less effective than sodium fluoride; it loses its effectiveness quickly on exposure to air, and has to be used in larger quantity. Borax, also, is less satisfactory than sodium fluoride. It is easily obtainable, however, and mixed with equal parts of powdered sweet chocolate, is a fairly effective remedy. Superheating and fumigation with hydrocyanic acid gas are also effective in destroying cockroaches. In the case of hydrocyanic acid gas fumigation, however, our experiments indicate that a concentration of 1 per cent, or burning 2 lbs. of calcium cyanide per 1,000 cubic feet, although effective against nymphs and adults, does not destroy the eggs."

The cost of the ingredients required will be quite small, and it is considered that you should purchase same locally.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Secretary.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to the boy Walter Heil Injil No. 115 mentioned in your letter of Oct. 2 under the No. 65-1-22, I beg to say I have consulted with the two Indian Agents T.J. Godfrey of Chapleau and John M. Daly of Parry Sound, as he came from that District.

I shall be very glad to learn what you think of this idea. Perhaps you will be too urgent to take the matter up with Inspector McGookin. Dear Mr. Pratt:

I write you regarding Walter Heil, a half-breed who is 21 years of age and a student of the Anglican School for Indian Children at Chapleau, Ontario. This boy is a cripple, having lost one of his legs some time ago. He is about to be discharged from the school, and my information is that the Department has refused to supply him with an artificial leg. It is stated that he is a very promising student and has his junior matriculation, and if he is discharged now without some further education he will be a burden on the community.

I would appreciate it very much if you would look into this matter and see if something can be done to assist this boy in completing his education, and if possible to assist him in securing an artificial limb. Anything you can do to help this boy will be greatly appreciated.

Thanking you for your attention to this matter, I am

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Thos. Farquhar
Thos. Farquhar, M. P.

May 20th, 1935.

Dear Sir:

When you last applied for an artificial leg for Walter Heil, the Department's funds were so low that it did not think it could grant your request at that time. A friend has now interceded for him, and the Department's funds being in somewhat better condition it is prepared to discuss the matter again. A great deal of money has been expended for the education of this young man who is not actually a ward of the Government. He must face the prospect of earning a living for himself, and, if an artificial leg would make it possible for him to do so, the Department is willing to consider providing it.

First, however, I should like to inquire what plans he may have in mind for his own future.

At the least calculation, his appliance will cost about $150. This sum of money can be put to very good advantage otherwise, as, for example, in providing the services of a dentist for about five days at your school. In short, the Department is willing to help the young man in this respect, if he has any definite plan for his own future self support.

Yours truly,

R. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

Dear Mr. Farquhar:

I have secured some information on the case of Walter Hall on whose behalf you wrote on May 15th. This boy is not a legal ward of the Dominion Government but as a matter of compassion the Department has provided twelve years schooling for him, including a course in the Collegiate Institute. He is now 21 years old and the Department holds, with, I should think some reason, that it has fairly done its duty toward him.

It will cost about $150.00 to provide this young man with an artificial leg. The request came in during the winter at a time when the Department feared that the appropriation for such purposes would be over-extended. It is so difficult to make the appropriation for medical services cover the requirements of the service that it was thought at that time that money could not be spared for this purpose. I will ask the officers of the Department to look into the matter now and I think their attitude may depend somewhat on what plans the young man may have for his own self-support.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of May 24th No. 65-1-13 with reference to an artificial leg for Walter Heil. I beg to say I have gone carefully into the matter with him as to what he would like to do when he leaves the school as he must before very long.

I pointed out it would be a long time before he could get through for a Teacher and he sees the truth of that. He says he would like to take up a regular bookkeeping course at a good school, like the Shaw Schools in Toronto or similar Training place so he could be fitted for office work.

I think with his education here he could get through in one year if the Department could help him to that extent and he would then be able to earn his living. It is true the Department have spent a lot of money on him. It would seem poor policy to drop him now and lose all the good done, when a little more would bring credit to the Department, to our school, and to himself.

I am delighted to learn this is a chance for him to get this artificial leg and so fit him for his future career as outlined above.

I shall be very glad to operate in any way I can to help you in this undertaking for which I thank you most sincerely.

His High School examinations will close in June and he could then be fitted to go to the hospital at your bidding.

Yours most respectfully,

A.J. Vale Principal.

Sir:

Replying to yours of Oct. 28th, 65-1-13 re Walter Hell, I have been in communication with Rev. Mr. J. Vale, principal of the Chapleau School re this matter at various times. I look upon this as a problem case and I recommended to the Department that he get an artificial leg when he would be full grown.

In pondering over the business course for Neil, my mind goes back to Alexander Decaire who was a member of the Wilson Band, and who has been enfranchised. This lad took a business course at McGill University and it appears to me that there was a lot of money spent on him for the benefit he has got out of it. He does a little bookkeeping at Baie where he is living now and I honestly do not look upon him as a bright and shining light in his community.

My idea is, that if Hell is inclined in that way, for his step-father and mother to make some provisions for him to stay with them at Laughnawaga and if he feels inclined to take a business course, he would be nearer a centre where he could make use of it. Canan Vale and his wife tell me that this boy is quite smart. Mr. Rankin Nesbitt and his wife tell me that the Williams boy at Moose Point is also smart. I cannot see it.

My recommendation is that Neil's step-father and mother be asked to look after the boy and encourage him in his desire for a business education. In this way if he has the ambition he will get there.
EX'D.

Dear Sir:

I consulted Dr. Sheahan of Charlevoix in connection with the little girl Mary Marsden, age 4 yrs., sent to us recently from the Saguenay Reserve. This girl is a diabetic child of a very active temperament requiring almost constant personal attention to attend her needs as she frequently falls down in convulsions during the day and at night cries out for a long period and then goes off in a convulsion. This disturbs the whole dormitory.

We have had to send her, at different times, to the hospital for the doctors to observe and prescribe treatment. We fear some calamity may overtake her without constant care. We are not equipped for this sort of case.

Would it be possible for you to arrange for her to be sent to some institution that could provide the care she needs. She is too young for the classroom and our supervisor cannot give the personal supervision needed.

February 24, 1939.

Dear Doctor Sheahan:

We have a letter from Canon Vale about Mary Marsden.

We knew this child had diabetes, but no one told us she had convulsions. She was sent to school as the only apparent means of clearing up a most deplorable situation from where she came. Her mother has husband and three children, and also an unofficial husband and five children of whom this is the second youngest.

Apparently, she will have to be taken off Canon Vale's hands. What I wish you would tell me is whether she has any good prospect of living long, and if so, whether she is a candidate for entrance to an institution for mental defectives or epileptics, or whether she could be placed under the auspices of a Children's Aid Society somewhere.

I do not think there is any hope of returning her to her mother who has gone back to her original family and husband. If she is not likely to live long, it might be as well to keep her in the hospital at Champlain if they can manage her there.

Canon Vale will receive a copy of this letter and I am sure you will wish to consult further with him.

Dear Doctor Stone:

Re. Mary Marsden, about whom Canon Vale wrote you last month,

As this child apparently still continues subject to these attacks of convulsions, I believe it would be best to have her transferred to the hospital here for further observation.

She is now taking fifteen units daily of insulin and evidently requires that much, even on a strict diabetic diet. A child of four requiring that amount indicates a bad prognosis.

It is doubtful if these convulsions are really epileptic and we should be able to decide in two or three weeks what kind of institution would be best for her. She could, of course, be admitted to the hospital as soon as you give permission for her admission.

Dear Sir:

Honourable Sir,

We beg leave to state in reference to a Boarding School for Indian children at Fort Frances:

Firstly, That there is only one Day School on Rainy Lake (an old dilapidated building on Couchiching reserve) and there are six Reserves, each entitled to a school.

Secondly, That it was due to the prospect of having a Boarding School at Fort Frances that no day schools were constructed on the Reserves; a saving of several thousand dollars being effected for the Government. Correspondence to this effect can be found at the Head Office in Winnipeg.

Thirdly, That education is becoming urgent in that district as the mining industry has taken hold there and the country is overrun by prospectors. Living conditions have materially changed of late.

Fourthly, That an educational establishment at or near Fort Frances will be under the public eye, nearly as much as Rat Portage, especially as it will be on the international boundary, hence the necessity for making provision for an institution that will be creditable to our country. Moreover, as it is destined to take the place of several day Schools, excepting the day school of Couchiching Reserve, would it not be advisable to provide accommodation for at least 40 children, even if the number to be admitted were limited to twenty for the first year.

You will be convinced of the necessity of the work when I tell you that during the whole winter water had to be drawn with horses and carried up stairs in pails to flush the closets. I need not insist on the inconveniences of such a system. I therefore ask of you to pay the full cost of that very necessary work which had to be done without delay. The material has been bought at wholesale price, and wages fair and just, considering the hard work done, have been paid.

Sir:

Referring to the number of pupils allowed at the Fort Frances Boarding School, I would respectfully recommend that the grant be increased to provide for fifty pupils.

My reasons are that an aggregate allowance for forty pupils would not cover the necessary expenditure, and therefore the school has a deficit each year, but an allowance for fifty pupils would, it is thought, cover all expenditure.

The building can accommodate fifty pupils as easily as forty and they have sufficient furniture on hand for the larger number. Again if this number is granted they could afford to have two teachers, whereas they only have one now, which in my opinion is not sufficient.

(1) An automobile trip would have to be made to the school (about three and one half miles each way) each visit. While I have my own auto, and would try to keep down cost, this could entail extra expense in time and a reasonable amount for use of auto., besides the work would probably extend into the winter months when an auto could not be used.

(2) In winter, the days become shorter and darker. My office is equipped with proper electric lighting equipment for dental work. On many fall and winter days up here, it is impossible to do proper work without proper dental lighting equipment, and during these seasons the light in the mornings and evenings is nearly always poor, unless augmented by electric light.

(3) I have in my office here-up-to-date electric and also chemical Dental Sterilization equipment. The sterilization of instruments used in this work must be carefully done and can be done more effectively in my office and by my nurse than can be at the school.

(4) There is no proper dental chair at the school. I would be obliged to put one of my chairs up there to work efficiently. This would also entail extra expense.

(5) I have a very fine, to me, of the best electric and water meters at my office in town, electric lights and various other things which it would be almost impossible to move back and forth. I have lost money I could use but not as satisfactorily.

(6) While I make every effort to avoid causing children pain, sometimes we cannot avoid causing some pain. When we do, it is just as well that the other children who are to be operated on later, should not be in the immediate vicinity as the psychological effect is bad.

(7) Summing it all up, I would say that this work can be done better and at less cost than at my office in town than at the school.

Father Brassard and his sisters are unable to run their office and in town on other business, there is telephone connection to the school and appointments can easily be made and the children brought down two or three at a time as has been done in the past. The work will probably extend over several months but I am sure the children will be given more satisfactory service if handled in that way, and at less cost to the department.

It is impossible for me to give a bulk estimate of the cost but I would charge the same as I do for public school children, which is as follows:

Dear Sir:  

In reference to the matter of Dental attention for the children of the Industrial school here, about which you requested information as to cost etc., I beg to say—  

Recently there has been a more active movement among the Dentists of Ontario towards saving the children's teeth and to that end, many Dentists have volunteered to examine the teeth of the school children of their locality. I was appointed by the Public School Board here to examine the teeth of the children of the Public Schools. I did this without cost to the school board and when the examination was completed, and as a further extension of the work, I decided that it was only fair to the children of the Industrial school to give them an equal chance with the white children.  

After being given permission by Father Brassard and Dr. Moore, my nurse and myself went over to examine at the school.  

In order to leave the whole matter in the hands of your department to take such action in regard to the matter as they might see fit, we handed over all records (both originals and carbon copies) to Father Brassard. If your Department decides to have the work done, I would suggest having one set of records handed over to the Dentist appointed to do the work. No charge will be made by me for this examination.  

I also extracted quite a number of temporary teeth whose extraction was urgently required and for this have charged $3.00 each.  

For the children of the Public Schools, who are having their teeth attended to, I am making a decided reduction in fees and will gladly do the same for the children of the Industrial School.  

In the letter from the Department, it is stated that the work should be done at the school. I believe this would be a mistake for several reasons:—  

(1) In my office in town, I have my nurse who has been trained to assist me in the work and is of special value in working on the teeth of children. I presume I could take her with me on my trips to the school but that would at present mean the closing of my office each time, leaving no one to answer telephonic calls and make appointments.  

At a later date, I expect to have a graduate assistant again, and if the Department decides that the proposed experiment justified setting up a chair and equipment at the school, I would then be in a position to handle future work for the children at the school, but at present I do not think expense would be necessary or justified.
Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 23rd instant, relative to the dental defects of the pupils of the Fort Frances Boarding School, I have the honor to enclose a letter from Dr. Reeves, who made the examination of these children and I think he has covered the ground very fully. It would be absurd for me who knows nothing about such matters and not having the Doctor's report, to try and make an estimate of the cost this work would entail, if the Doctor who made the examination considers it impossible to do so.

I quite agree with the Doctor regarding the work being done at his Office and not at the School.

I also enclose a letter from Dr. Bell of this town, who is the only Dentist besides Dr. Reeves here, and in my conversation with him, he informed me that the work could be better done in his office than at the school.

I have the honor to be,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th instant, regarding the trouble which is being occasioned at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School by the action of the Chief and Councillors of the Band, who claim the right to visit and inspect the school whenever they desire to do so.

In this connection I have to say that, under Section 9 (6) of the Indian Act, the Chief and Council of a band have the right to inspect a school at which children of the band attend, at such reasonable times only as may be agreed upon by the Indian Agent and the Principal of the School. It is considered that not more than two visits each year by the Chief and Councillors should be sufficient and these visits should be made only at times convenient to the Agent and yourself. The Chief and Council have no right to visit the school indiscriminately and interfere with the regular routine of the classroom. During their visit, they have no right to inspect the books or accounts.

I am forwarding a copy of this letter to Mr. Agent Spencer and requesting him to give definite instructions to the Chief and Councillors that before they make any visit, they are to arrange with the Agent and yourself, and they should be accompanied each time by the Indian Agent. Their visits should be made at a time when the regular classroom work will not be disrupted.

The above instructions are not to interfere in any way with the regular visiting hours set aside by the school authorities for the parents to call and see their children.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
